title: Alexandru Moldovan
text:
Alexandru Moldovan (born 23 August 1950, in <a href="Ocna%20Mure%C8%99">Ocna Mureș</a>) is a <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Coach%20%28sport%29">manager</a> and former <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a>.
Career.
Playing career.
Moldovan played for <a href="FC%20Dinamo%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Dinamo Bucharest</a>, <a href="FC%20Bihor%20Oradea">Crişul Oradea</a>, <a href="Jiul%20Petro%C8%99ani">Jiul Petroșani</a>, <a href="FC%20Progresul%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Progresul București</a>, <a href="Victoria%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Victoria București</a>, Metallurgistul Cugir and <a href="FC%20Unirea%20Alba%20Iulia">Unirea Alba Iulia</a> from 1970 and 1985 until his retirement.
During his playing career Moldovan won four <a href="Liga%20I">League</a> titles in eight years with Dinamo Bucharest.
Coaching career.
Moldovan coached a number of teams in his native <a href="Romania">Romania</a>, including most notably <a href="FC%20Dinamo%20Bucharest">Dinamo Bucharest</a> in the 1992–93 season. His side lost 2–0 on aggregate to eventual winners <a href="Olympique%20de%20Marseille">Olympique de Marseille</a> in the <a href="1992%E2%80%9393%20UEFA%20Champions%20League">second round</a> qualifiers for the group stage of the <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">UEFA Champions League</a> in 1993. In the same year he left Romania to coach clubs in <a href="Kuwait">Kuwait</a>, <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>, <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>, <a href="Algeria">Algeria</a>, <a href="Bahrain">Bahrain</a>, <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a> and <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>.
Moldovan had three successful spells as manager of <a href="Raja%20Casablanca">Raja Casablanca</a>. During his first era in charge, Raja won the <a href="Botola">Moroccan league</a> title in 1997. In his second stint Raja had surprisingly sacked him in the 2001–02 season when they were seven points clear in the standings but officials felt the team were not playing attractive football and Raja ended up third after replacing him. During his third spell at the club Moldovan won the <a href="Coupe%20du%20Tr%C3%B4ne">Coupe du Trône</a> and led the Moroccan side to the semifinals of the <a href="CAF%20Champions%20League">CAF Champions League</a> in <a href="2005%20CAF%20Champions%20League">2005</a> losing 2–0 on aggregate against Tunisian side <a href="%C3%89toile%20du%20Sahel">Étoile du Sahel</a>. Moldovan was fired and replaced by <a href="Oscar%20Fullon%C3%A9">Oscar Fulloné</a> in December 2005.
